name: 1579_C. Ticks
description:
Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered field of size n × m. Initially, all cells of the field are white.

Let us denote the cell with coordinates i vertically and j horizontally by (i, j). The upper left cell will be referred to as (1, 1) and the lower right cell as (n, m).

Casimir draws ticks of different sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn as follows: 

  1. First, the center cell (i, j) is painted black. 
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also painted black. 
  3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for all h between 0 and d are painted. In particular, a tick consists of 2d + 1 black cells. 



An already painted cell will remain black if painted again. Below you can find an example of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You are given a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field came about after he drew some (possibly 0) ticks on it. The ticks could be of different sizes, but the size of each tick is at least k (that is, d ≥ k for all the ticks).

Determine whether this field can indeed be obtained by drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

output:

prompt:
Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered grid that is n × m in size. At the start, each square on the grid is white.

Let's represent the cell with coordinates i downwards and j sideways by (i, j). The top left cell will be called (1, 1). The bottom right cell will be called (n, m).

Casimir sketches ticks of varying sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn in this manner:

  1. First, the central cell (i, j) is colored black.
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also colored black. 
  3. Therefore, all the cells at positions (i - h, j ± h) for every h from 0 to d are colored. Specifically, a tick is made up of 2d + 1 black cells.

A cell that is already painted will stay black if painted again. Below is an illustration of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You receive a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field was created by marking some (maybe 0) ticks on it. The ticks could vary in sizes, but each tick must have a size of at least k (that is, d ≥ k for every tick).

Evaluate whether this field can indeed result from drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not. Consider edge cases where the field dimensions or the values of k result in limited or no space for ticks.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---

The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid in the test cases can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of "YES" or "NO" for each test case indicating if the grid can be formed by ticks.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark the positions that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each position in the grid to see if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1
                    size -= 1  # Adjust size to the last valid tick size

                    if size >= k:
                        # Mark the positions of the tick
                        for s in range(size + 1):
                            marked[i - s][j - s] = True
                            marked[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid in the test cases can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of "YES" or "NO" for each test case indicating if the grid can be formed by ticks.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark the positions that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each position in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if this position can be the center of a tick of size at least k
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1
                    size -= 1  # Adjust size to the last valid tick size

                    if size >= k:
                        # Mark the positions of this tick
                        for s in range(size + 1):
                            marked[i - s][j - s] = True
                            marked[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        can_form = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    can_form = False
                    break
            if not can_form:
                break

        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if each grid in the test cases can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick can be formed centered at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and
                            i - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and
                            grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            marked[i - s][j - s] = True
                            marked[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Verify if all '*' cells are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid in the test cases can be formed by ticks of a minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): A list of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of "YES" or "NO" for each test case indicating if the grid can be formed by ticks.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a valid tick
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    valid_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    if valid_tick:
                        # Mark the cells of the tick
                        for d in range(k + 1):
                            marked[i - d][j - d] = True
                            marked[i - d][j + d] = True
                        marked[i][j] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        can_form = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    can_form = False
                    break
            if not can_form:
                break

        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid in the test cases can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Function to check if a tick of size `size` can be formed at position (i, j)
        def can_form_tick(i: int, j: int, size: int) -> bool:
            for d in range(size):
                if i - d < 0 or j - d < 0 or j + d >= m:
                    return False
                if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                    return False
            return True

        # Mark all possible ticks in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Try to form the largest possible tick centered at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while can_form_tick(i, j, size + 1):
                        size += 1
                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells
                    if size >= k:
                        for d in range(size):
                            marked[i - d][j - d] = True
                            marked[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Check if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        all_covered = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    all_covered = False
                    break
            if not all_covered:
                break

        results.append("YES" if all_covered else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid in the test cases can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a valid tick
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    valid_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    if valid_tick:
                        # Mark the cells of the tick
                        for d in range(k + 1):
                            marked[i - d][j - d] = True
                            marked[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        all_ticks_covered = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    all_ticks_covered = False
                    break
            if not all_ticks_covered:
                break

        if all_ticks_covered:
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid in the test cases can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of "YES" or "NO" for each test case indicating if the grid can be formed by ticks.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    valid_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    if valid_tick:
                        # Mark the cells of the tick
                        for d in range(k + 1):
                            marked[i - d][j - d] = True
                            marked[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        can_form = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    can_form = False
                    break
            if not can_form:
                break

        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if ticks of minimum size can be formed in each test case grid.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions, minimum tick size, and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        if is_valid_tick_grid(n, m, k, grid):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

def is_valid_tick_grid(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str]) -> bool:
    """Checks if a grid can form valid ticks of minimum size k.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        bool: True if the grid can form valid ticks, False otherwise.
    """
    # Create a 2D list to track visited cells
    visited = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

    # Iterate over each cell in the grid
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == '*' and not visited[i][j]:
                if not can_form_tick_from_center(i, j, k, n, m, grid, visited):
                    return False

    return True

def can_form_tick_from_center(i: int, j: int, k: int, n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], visited: List[List[bool]]) -> bool:
    """Attempts to form a tick from a given center cell.

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center cell.
        j (int): Column index of the center cell.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.
        visited (List[List[bool]]): 2D list to track visited cells.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a valid tick can be formed, False otherwise.
    """
    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed
    for size in range(1, k + 1):
        if (i - size < 0 or j - size < 0 or j + size >= m or
            grid[i - size][j - size] != '*' or grid[i - size][j + size] != '*'):
            return False

    # Mark the cells of the tick as visited
    for size in range(k + 1):
        visited[i - size][j - size] = True
        visited[i - size][j + size] = True

    return True

# Input interface
def main():
    """Main function to read input and output results."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a grid can form ticks of a minimum size k for each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions, minimum tick size, and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Initialize a 2D list to track tick formation
        can_form = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if this cell can be the center of a tick of size at least k
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and
                           i + size < n and j + size < m and
                           grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and
                           grid[i + size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells as part of a tick
                    if size >= k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            can_form[i - s][j - s] = True
                            can_form[i + s][j + s] = True

        # Check if all '*' in the grid can form a tick
        all_ticks_formed = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not can_form[i][j]:
                    all_ticks_formed = False
                    break
            if not all_ticks_formed:
                break

        results.append("YES" if all_ticks_formed else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
import sys
input = sys.stdin.read

def main():
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = [data[index + i + 1] for i in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
        index += n + 1

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell is part of a valid tick
        tick_grid = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check for possible ticks starting from each cell
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1

                    # If a valid tick of at least size k is found, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            tick_grid[i - s][j - s] = True
                            tick_grid[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not tick_grid[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
import sys
input = sys.stdin.read

def main():
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = [data[index + i + 1] for i in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
        index += n + 1

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.
